For example, I imagine a big red warning next to all of those very convenient offers to log on to a new web service using your Facebook or Google+ credentials. But my belief is that it will, at most, serve to cool its superheated engines. Just last week, Facebook engineers revealed that they had to lash together network switches with a snake pit of cables to keep up with their heady traffic growth last year. To keep pace with their forecasts, they said that they need within three years optical interfaces on network chips, bridging an opto-electrical chasm that engineers have avoided for decades. My bet is on a short-lived #DeleteFacebook movement followed by another long binge of social networking. Given the nascent state of neural-network-powered analytics, this roller coaster has many more ups and downs ahead and they will only get steeper.
